unnormalised: Tech giant, Infosys, just announced a new AI initiative, and honestly, it's either genius or they've been hitting the chai too hard. Apparently, they're developing AI to "solve the problem of perpetually delayed Indian Standard Time." You know, the one where meetings start 15 minutes late because "Sir, traffic was terrible!" They're calling it 'IST-AI' – original, right?
normalised: Tech giant, I-N-F-O-S-Y-S, just announced a new A-I initiative, and honestly, it's either genius or they've been hitting the chai too hard. Apparently, they're developing A-I to "solve the problem of perpetually delayed Indian Standard Time." You know, the one where meetings start fifteen minutes late because "Sir, traffic was terrible!" They're calling it 'I-S-T-A-I' – original, right?

unnormalised: According to sources (probably just someone overhearing shouting in the cafeteria), IST-AI will use advanced algorithms to predict traffic patterns, astrologically align schedules, and perhaps even teleport people. Imagine: no more frantic "I'm 5 mins away" calls when you're actually stuck near Dadar. Some say it'll predict when Sharmaji's scooter will break down, causing the delay.
normalised: According to sources (probably just someone overhearing shouting in the cafeteria), I-S-T-A-I will use advanced algorithms to predict traffic patterns, astrologically align schedules, and perhaps even teleport people. Imagine: no more frantic "I'm five minutes away" calls when you're actually stuck near Dadar. Some say it'll predict when Sharmaji's scooter will break down, causing the delay.

unnormalised: But the real question is: can IST-AI predict when the company's own servers will crash during a demo? Or better yet, can it convince my auto-wala to use a meter? If it can do that, I'll buy Infosys stock. Until then, I'm setting my watch 10 mins ahead... just in case.
